title.value: Evolution of cell size control is canalized towards adders or sizers by cell cycle structure and selective pressures
title.justification: The title concisely reflects the paper's main topic, which is about how cell cycle structures and selective pressures influence the evolution of cell size control mechanisms towards adders or sizers.
title.quote: Evolution of cell size control is canalized towards adders or sizers by cell cycle structure and selective pressures

extractions.description: The paper presents research on the evolution of cell size control mechanisms, specifically how certain cellular structures and pressures guide these mechanisms towards either adders or sizers. The study uses evolutionary simulations to explore these dynamics within cell cycle structures akin to those found in different organisms, demonstrating a tendency for different phases to support either adding a constant size or compensating for initial size differences in a cycle. A significant aspect of this research is its use of computational models to simulate and evaluate these developmental processes.

type.justification: The research is primarily based on computational simulations and theoretical modeling of cell size control mechanisms rather than empirical experiments.
type.quote: This paper develops evolutionary simulations to identify the type of molecular networks that can give rise to size control.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on computational simulations of biological processes, which falls under the domain of Computational Biology.
name.quote: Research article­­­­ Computational and Systems Biology

name.justification: The study investigates cell size control mechanisms at a systems level, exploring how different network structures evolve under specific selection pressures.
name.quote: The paper develops evolutionary simulations to identify the type of molecular networks that can give rise to size control.

name.justification: The research applies evolutionary algorithms, a concept from evolutionary biology, to study the development of cell size control mechanisms.
name.quote: Evolutionary algorithms are a class of machine learning techniques aiming at mimicking evolutionary processes.

name.justification: Model A1 is explicitly named and discussed as part of the simulations performed in the study.
name.quote: We chose one simple model to illustrate the control mechanism common to our set of evolved networks (Model A1 shown in Figure 2B).

is_contributed.justification: Model A1 is developed and used as part of the research to illustrate evolved size control mechanisms.
is_contributed.quote: Model A1’s initial and Slope before evolu­ tion are indicated by the dashed black line.

is_executed.justification: Model A1 is used in computational simulations as part of the evolutionary study.
is_executed.quote: we plot the amount of volume added ∆V for different phases of the cell cycle as a function of the initial volume

is_compared.justification: Model A1 is compared with other evolved models and analytical archetypes such as adders and sizers.
is_compared.quote: Model A1 follows approximately the adder archetype over a large range of control volumes.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Model A1 is a part of the paper's novel contributions and is not referenced from another paper.

name.justification: The paper mentions using phi-evo, a software tool, for simulating evolutionary processes in biological systems.
name.quote: The models used in this study are publicly available (Proulx-­Giraldeau and François, 2022).

referenced_paper_title.value: phi-evo: a program to evolve phenotypic models of biological networks
referenced_paper_title.justification: The phi-evo tool is referenced as part of the methods section, where its utility in evolving models is discussed.
referenced_paper_title.quote: φ-evo: a program to evolve phenotypic models of biological networks. PLOS Computational Biology 14:e1006244.
